div.p:
Supra dictum est Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 6, n. 1
etc. After the Master posited his intention about love in the first and show how charity receives intension in the second part, now in this third part in introduces an opposing opinion. And he divides it in the first place into two parts because in the first place he introduces the aforementioned opinion, in the second place he add a conclusion. The second begins at
Hic quaeritur, si Spiritus Sanctus Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 6, n. 13 . The first part is divided in three according to the three motives with which those opining in this way argue, for in the first place they argue from the description of divine and created charity, in the second place from the operation of the Holy Spirit, in the third place from the description of created charity. The second begins at,
Sed aliud est, inquiunt Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 6, n. 7 . The third beings at
alias quoque inducunt rationes Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 6, n. 9 , etc.

That not in the first place because, if God is able to make something please from what is not pleasing without such a habit, then he is manifestly able to make something pleasing from what is not that has this habit in itself. The consequent is false. Again, it follows that God is able by himself alone to make that a white thing is without producing whiteness and that man exists without producing humanity, which are false. And the consequences are clear because the argument does not seem to about one more than another.

In the second place principally, it would follow that God would be able to be the formal ratio making the will pleasing. The consequence is clear, the falsity is proved because, if so, then it follows that it would be possible there to be motion of ordered love in the created mind. The consequent is false since motion indicates an imperfection.

In the third place, if God were able to withdraw rectitude from the mind, it follows that it would be able to make a sinning mind. The consequent is false because no one is bad from God as author according to
Augustine Augustinus, XXX . The consequence is clear because every mind lacking rectitude is unjust. This seems to be the opinion of
Anselm, in his book On the Free Will, in chapter 4
Anselmus, De libero arbitrio, c. 4, xxx .

In opposition, it is argued that the first part has already shown above, but the second is proved because rectitude and the will are absolutely distinct things, therefore God is able to separate one from the other. And as a consequence he is able possible to separate and remove the will from its rectitude, therefore.

First conclusion: though from the ordered law no one is able to be pleasing from what is not pleasing without infused charity, nevertheless from the absolute or possible law it is possible that the one not having this charity is more greatly pleasing to God than another having it and ordinately loves God with a greater intensity. The first part is clear from what has been said. The second part is proved because the Holy Spirit alone actuates the mind and elevates it to God for loving more intensely than in fact a certain pilgrim who has this habit of created charity in the mind, therefore. The antecedent was clear above.

First corollary: although concerning the common law created charity is required for a pilgrim to be pleasing, nevertheless no created charity is required to act meritoriously to act well. The first is apparent because no one is pleasing without this habit. The second part is proved because if any charity is given the pilgrim would be able to act meritoriously with that created charity.

The second corollary: any created mind eliciting a meritorious act of love loves God infinitely more than is absolutely necessary. This is proved both because it is not absolutely necessary that the created mind loves God and secondly because the mind would be able to
love God meritoriously with infinitely less charity or love.

Third corollary: the identity between whiteness and being white is greater than between created charity and being pleasing . This is clear because nothing is able to be white without whiteness, but it is possible to be pleasing without this charity.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p:
The second conclusion: though it is not repugnant to the Holy Spirit to be a formal power by which the power meritoriously an act of love, nevertheless it is repugnant to the Holy Spirit to be for the created mind the motion of ordinate love. The first is clear because to be such a formal power indicates no imperfection, indeed it indicates perfection and excludes everything repugnant, as was seen above, therefore. This is confirmed through
Blessed Augustine, IV De Trinitate, capitulo 18
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IV, c. 3, n. 5 (PL 42:XX)
explaining that passage
We know that we will be like him when he appears
I Ioannes 3:2 . The second is clear because such motion indicates an imperfection, namely potentiality, but the Holy Spirit is the highest act excluding from itself every potentiality, therefore.

The first corollary: this denomination of love should be more greatly applied to the formal ratio than to the vital motion of love. This is clear because this ratio per se and intrinsically is called love, but this motion is only called love extrinsically because it is determined to this love.

The second corollary: that not every formal ratio of formal love a being of the highest perfection is a mode of acting well or of meritorious loving because the Holy Spirit is or is able to be the ratio of this and not of motion.

Third corollary: that the one having the meritorious motion of love has the habit of charity is not necessary, and conversely it is not necessary that the one having the habit of charity joined to the mind has the motion of love. This is clear through the conclusion, and it is confirmed because to the grace of predestination alone corresponds the being of one meritorious from the power of divine acceptance, therefore. This was also made clear above.

Third conclusion: though God is able to introduce no latitude of guilt to human beings, nevertheless God is able to remove the rectitude of the will from human beings. The first part is clear because then such a person would become worse from God as author, against
Augustine, in 83 quaestiones, in question 5
Augustinus, 83 questiones, q. 5 . In the second case it is proved because everything that is not the will God is able to separate and remove from it, but the rectitude of the will is not the will, therefore. The major is known because everything that is absolutely distinct, God etc. The minor is clear because rectitude and the created will, if they were the same, it would follow that every created will would be upright, indeed it would further follows that no will would be able to sine because then every will would be formally justice and rectitude, which is false, therefore.

First corollary: any absolute rectitude of a human will really includes the latitude of gratifying gratitude of charity. This is clear because, if not, then it would follows that the will would be able to have it from itself or from another creature, against the
Venerable Anselm On the Free Will, in chapter 14
Anselmus, De libero arbitrio, c. 14, xxx .

The second corollary: it is the case that the personal mind is in the entire latitude of rectitude and never demerits some latitude of penalty or reprentance. This is clear because, if God deprived as creature of rectitude, he would still not love it less, indeed he would be able to accept a greater prize than before, if he wished.

Third corollary: it is the case that a person deprived of the rectitude of the will is not also unjust, but would be just. This is clear because God is able to deprive someone of rectitude and is not able to inflict injustice or malice. From this it is clear what should be said to the question.

Contra primam conclusionem arguitur, si non esset simpliciter necessariam aliquam creaturam esse iustam, sequeretur quod Deus oppositum illius
quod aeternaliter ordinavit posset facere. Consequens est falsum quia tunc Deus esset mutabilis. Et consequentia patet quia, si non necessario sic est sicut ordinavit, oppositum evenire. Confirmatur quia aeternaliter praedestinando a voluit ipsum fore iustum. Secundo quia lex ordinata est absolute necessaria, igitur quidquid est necessariam secundum illam est absolute necessariam, sed secundum illam est necessariam hominem carum habere caritatem creatam, ergo. Antecedens patet quia omne aeternum absolute est necessariam lex aeterna est necessaria, igitur.
Secundo, contra primum corollarium: si nulla gratia requiritur ad bene operandum meritorie, ergo nullam gratiam habendo quis posset salvari de lege ordinata.

Tertio Quarto
contra secundum corollarium: non quilibet gradus caritatis sufficit ad fortem temptationem vincendum vel ad martyrium patiendum propter Deum, ergo nec sufficit ad quodlibet opus meritorium exercendum. Et per consequens, si minori caritate diligeret, non sufficienter diligeret.

Contra secundam conclusionem: mentem uniri Deo beatifice sine motu potentiae ad obiectum repugnat, ergo Spiritus Sanctus non potest esse formaliter ratio percipiendi Deum beatifice seu dilectionis meritorie. Consequentia tenet cum talis motus repugnet Spiritui Sancto. Et antecedens probatur quia aliter sequeretur quod tale obiectum beatificum esset essentialiter et intrinsece praesens creatae potentiae quod est falsum quia soli Deo sic est praesens.

Secundo, contra primum corollarium: sequeretur si huiusmodi motus staret sine terminis quod non esset perceptio seu vitalis operatio. Consequens est falsum. Probatur consequentia quia omnis perceptio vitalis competit sibi solum terminative extrinsece, ut dicit corollarium.
Tertio, nullus talis motus est ponendus ego antecedens patet quia hoc esset propter distantiam potentiae ab obiecto et hoc non quia deus semper est praesens potentiae

Quarto, si tertium corollarium esset verum, sequeretur quod in aliquo posset esse caritas gratuita, et tamen ille non esset carus Deo nec acceptus consequens est contra veritatem. Item sequitur Deum non esse bonum. Patet quia ille non est bonus qui non de bonis gaudet operationibus ut habetur
I Ethicorum Aristoteles, Ethica, I, xxx .

Contra tertiam conclusionem: si auferret Deus a voluntate rectitudinem aut hoc faceret nolens aut volens. Non primum quia Deus nihil operatur nolens nec secundum quia cum rectitudo voluntatis sit velle quo Deus vult ipsam velle, sequitur quod Deus posset velle voluntatem non velle quod vult eam velle, sed hoc implicat, ergo.

Secundo, contra primum corollarium stat rectitudo voluntatis cum peccato mortali, ergo non includit gratiam gratificantem. Patet consequentia et antecedens patet per
Anselmum De libero arbitrio, capitulo 13
dicentem,
volens habere rectitudinem habet rectitudinem
Anselmus, De libero arbitrio, c. 13, xxx , sed existens in mortali peccato potest velle havere rectitudinem, ergo.

Tertio, arguitur per
Anselmus ibidem capitulo 14
dicens
omnem habentem rectitudinem dici potest habere iustitiam et esse iustum quia omnis habens iustitiam iustus est non tamen sensio iustis hominibus esse promissam perpetuam vitam sed illis tantum qui sunt iusti sine omni iniustitia
Anselmus, De libero arbitrio, c. 14, xxx .

Quarto, contra tertium et secundum corollaria: privatio iustitiae et rectitudinis est formaliter culpa, ergo cuilibet tali debetur pena. Consequentia tenet et antecedens est
Anselmus in De casu diaboli capitulo 4
dicens
diabolus inquit perdidit iustitiam originalem in qua factus et pro ea invenit privationem eius qui nullam habet essentiam quam iniustitiam nominamus
Anselmus, De casu diaboli, c. 4, xxx .

Ad primum, potest consequentia negari quia talis motus vitalis non est aliquid distinctum ab ipsa vitali potentia. Secundo, potest dici quod Deus se solo potest mentem beatifice sine quacumque alia quantitate quacumque incomplexa, non tamen sine quolibet complexo se habere, et haec solutio est primae rationis contra secundam conclusionem.
Ad primum contra primam, conceditur consequens de his quae non sunt praeterita nec posita inesse loquendo ratio est quia quod ab aeterno voluit potest numquam voluisse.

Ad secundum, conceditur antecedens quia lex illa
est Deus, sed negatur consequentia quia tunc omnia evenirent de necessitate quod est falsum. Secundo potest dici quod lex potest sumi dupliciter, uno modo pro aliquo in Christo quod est Deus, alio modo pro aliquo complexo quod est dictum aliquod aeternaliter ordinasse. Primo modo conceditur antecedens et negatur consequentia. Secundo modo negatur antecedens et conceditur consequentia.
Ad tertium, negatur consequentia.

Ad quartum, negatur antecedens quia, licet caritas minor non inclinet intensive sicut magna, tamen ad omnem actum ad quem maior inclinat etiam minor inclinat seu inclinare potest. Secundo posset negari illa consequentia a caritas non sufficit ad faciendum voluntatem velle subire martyrium, ergo non sufficit ad Deum sufficienter diligendum.
Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem iam dictum est.

Ad secundum, conceditur consequens, sicut enim altero numquam proprie dicitur generatio nisi sequatur terminus genitus, ita talis motus non diceretur vitalis perceptio nisi terminus vitaliter percipiatur.

Ad tertium, negatur antecedens et ad probationem dico quod, licet Deus sit semper praesens realiter, non tamen obiective vitaliter unde talis motus est reddere rem non praesentem obiectaliter. Secundo, dico quod dato quod Deus sit semper sufficienter praesens animae obiectaliter, adhuc anima indiget tali motu propter alia obiecta extrinseca quae non sunt vitaliter
praesentia
pi
potentiae.

Ad quartum, dicitur consequens de eius potentia absoluta, nec ex hoc sequitur contradictio loquendo de eius acceptatione ad vitam aeternam, nec sequitur Deum non esse bonum quia, licet non acceptet illud opus ad vitam aeternam acceptat, tamen ad aliquid quod pro ipso reddet vel reddidit.

Ad aliam sequitur Deum non esse iustum retributorem etc., hic dicit
Gregorius, distinctione 17 primi, quaestione prima, articulo secundo, corollario secundo, conclusionis secundae Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 17, q. 1, a. 2, concl. 2, corr. 2, xxx , quod nec vitae aeternae nec cuiuscumque primi aeterni vel temporalis aliquis actus hominis ex quacumque caritate elicitus est ex condigno meritorius quod sibi bonum videbitur et potest negari consequentia.
Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, posset dici quod nec sic nec sit sed non volendo huius rectitudinem servare.
Aliter dicit Adam et Bonsemblantes quod volens, et conceditur consequens quod infertur in sensu diviso. Prima solutio securior videtur.

Ad secundum, potest dici quod rectitudo potest sumi dupliciter, uno modo simpliciter, alio modo secundum quid. Sed Anselmus loquitur de rectitudine secundum quid. Corollarium vero intelligitur de
rectitudine
servi
simpliciter dicta. Secundo, potest dici quod velle est duplex primum est efficax indicativum. Secundum est efficax optativum de primo loquitur Anselmus dicens quod quid vult rectitudinem scilicet efficaciter indicative habet illam et talem velle non stat cum mortali sed bene secundum.
Ad tertium dicitur Anselmus non loquitur de rectitudine vel iustitia simpliciter, sed secundum quid, ut patet intuenti eius verba, ideo nihil concludit contra dicta.

Ad quartum, conceditur antecedens de facto, sed in casu quo Deus auferret rectitudinem a voluntate sine demerito voluntatis, talis privatio non esset culpa, nec verba Anselmus probat oppositum quia iustitia mali angelis fuit sibi inesse, ideo eius privatio fuit peccatum, non autem sit esset de iustitia istius quam Deus privaret rectitudine sua sine sue peccato. Ad rationes in oppositum patet solutio per dicta superius.

Supra dictum est. Lombardus, I, d. 17, c. 6, n. 1
Prima conclusio quod Spiritus Sanctus operatur in nobis actum credendi est spirandi me?bus virtutibus, scilicet fide et spe actum vero diligendi doctores ponunt quod operatur in nobis sine alicuius virtutis medio vel sine habitu creato.

Et nota quod
Magister hic Lombardus, I, d. 17, xxx
videtur negare caritatem creatam, ideo communiter hic non tenetur quia praeter actum diligendi ponunt doctores habitum creatum caritatis. Alii vero sunt quid volunt
salvare Magistrum dicens quod Magister non intendit huiusmodi habitum negare haec aut relinquo iudicio legentis.

Secunda conclusio quod per donum quod est Spiritus Sanctus dantur dona et dividuntur non enim singuli habent omnia dona sed hi illa alii alia quamvis omnes habeant ipsum donum, scilicet Spiritum Sanctum a quo omnia dona cuiusquamque dividuntur.
